events.name: Learning Haskell and using Yesod as a production API backend by @Calvin Cheng
events.description: Haskell is an obscure language in comparison with other popular languages/frameworks like python/django, ruby/rails, javascript/nodejs and is usually not considered in 'mainstream' start-up projects. I decided to take a look and found it an impressive language that I am comfortable using, for a new production app in my company. Our current app uses golang for the API backend. I would like to share my experiences (and pain :-p) learning the language and why I am happy with it as our API backend for a new app.
events.location: Plug-In@Blk71

events.name: TGIFHacks#29 - Scalability @ Viki
events.description: Hey Guys, This week a team from Viki would be joining us once again, this time to talk about how Viki scales its backend API to serve millions of users worldwide. Viki is a global TV site that streams TV shows, movies and other premium content. In recent times, the popularity of their service exploded and as a result they attract tens of millions of visitors daily. Keeping everything running smoothly is a massive feat of engineering at the backend. Join us this week to know more about this rapid growth and how the engineering team at Viki keeps the infrastructure together as they continue to attract more users and grow rapidly. Speaker Profile: Minh Đỗ is a Platform Engineer at Viki. Along with his team, he is responsible for the development and maintenance of the Viki platform API, whose clients include the Viki website at www.viki.com, the various mobile clients (Android, iOS, Windows Phone, etc.) and other third party clients (Samsung TVs, Xbox, etc.). Note: Viki is on the lookout for interns and full time hires so if you're looking for employment opportunities, we would encourage you to talk to the engineers and find out more. Pizzas would be served so come hungry! :) P.S. The speaker also happens to be an alumnus of the OSS :)
events.location: TR+37

events.name: Friday Hacks #88 - 20 Ways to Get Involved with the Developer Community
events.description: Ever wanted to get involved in the tech/developer community but don't know where to start? Come down to Friday Hacks this week to learn about it! Venue: SR3, Town Plaza, UTown Free pizza is served before the talks. Talk description How can a student or anyone curious get involved with the developer community beyond school or work? And why? This talk will scan through the developer scene both locally, globally, online or on-ground and give examples on where anyone can contribute, get involved and get more information about the vibrant technology scene. What communities can you join easily and learn? Which meetups can you attend and even help to co-organize? How to start contributing to open source? Can we easily share with by writing our own blogs, books or even making podcasts? What are some interesting twitter accounts or blogs to follow? How can we add in short trips to engage with locals while traveling anywhere in the world? We will discuss all these questions and more! Speaker profile Sayanee Basu is a full stack developer working with emerging web technologies at Ricoh Pte. Ltd. in Singapore. Her key interest lies in connecting the web and the internet to the physical world through sensors and hence, much of her free time is now spent in tinkering with electronics and computer networks. She creates Build Podcast, a screencast series on developer tools as well as actively contributes to the Singapore tech community through curation of events, open source projects at webuild.sg and a developer focused podcast with We Build LIVE. She graduated from National University of Singapore in Electrical Engineering. You can find out more about her at http://sayan.ee! Our Sponsors Friday Hacks is sponsored by the NUS Enterprise Center and the Infocomm Development Authority. If you are looking to turn your ideas into a startup and would love some business support, feel free to get in touch with Jason from NUS Enterprise: jasontgw@nus.edu.sg
events.location: SR3, Town Plaza, UTown

events.name: #26: Building a Data Center-Lessons learnt
events.description: Hello! The next meetup will be hosted on the 25th of February. Mark your calendars! ************************** Talk Details ************************** Speaker - Sriram Narayanan @ ThoughtWorks In this session, Ram will cover the relevance of a Data Centre in these days of Cloud Computing, when and why you would still consider a Data Center despite having full competence with using Cloud Providers, how one selects a Data Centre for physical hosting of servers, understanding and negotiating Terms and Conditions, dealing with cabling, Racks, Power Supplies, switches, firewalls, UPS systems, practical risks that they have had to deal with, and finally understanding what a Data Centre will not offer. ************ Job Postings ************ If you are looking for people, message us a blurb (keep it short please) and a link to your job posting and we will put it here. 1. ThoughtWorks ThoughtWorks is synonymous with innovation. We are dedicated to the art of perfecting software delivery by keeping it lightweight, fast-moving and open-source. Our clients are people and organisations with ambitious missions - whether in the commercial, social, or government sectors. They trust us to deliver the disruptive thinking and technology that empowers them to succeed. We are currently looking for talented people in Singapore/ASEAN who are equally as passionate about software. If you are someone who loves the idea of helping the technical community locally to grow then we want to talk to you! https://jobs.thoughtworks.com/singapore/JobDetail/Singapore-Singapore-Software-Developers/897 Cheers, Tze Hon & Satyam
events.location: Thoughtworks, 87B Amoy Street #04, Singapore 069906, Singapore

events.name: Welcome to Data savvy, Insight driven, Big Data Meetup on 27th February
events.description: Dear Big Data Enthusiast, Join Singapore Big Data Meetup on 27th February to learn the latest on Big Data and Analytics driven cutting edge insight, business intelligence and ROI. The Meetup discussions will have specific focus on Introduction to Enterprise Big Data Platform, Big Data Analytics Demo, Taming Streaming data. Technology and culture all need to be in place and working cohesively to maximize the return of big data and analytics. The only requirement is to RSVP and stay connected with Singapore Big Data community. Additionally, you may invite your friends, colleagues, customers to this Meetup Time: 27th February 2015 from 9 am to 12 noon Venue: TEC room, Level 1, 9 Changi Business Park Central 1, The IBM Place, Singapore[masked] Agenda: • 9 am to 9:30 am Registration • 9:30 am to 10 am Keynote by Anup Kumar on Introduction to Enterprise Big Data Platform - A quick overview of what are the various tools and capability available from IBM for taming Big Data . • 10 am to 10:30 am Big Data Analytics Demo - How to leverage BigR, BigSheet , BigSQL and other Hadoop technology to gain Insight from variety of data. • 10:30 am to 11:30 am Taming Streaming data - How to leverage various big data tools and capability to build application that require handling geo spatial, switch and sensors data. • 11:30 to 12 noon Tea Break/Networking
events.location: IBM Singapore, TEC room, Level 1, 9 Changi Business Park Central 1, The IBM Place, Singapore 486048

events.name: WebRTC hackathon with the pros
events.description: We're very excited to host our first WebRTC hackathon in Singapore and get all our work around the Skylink platform into your hands. The good people of JFDI are so kind to host us for the entire Saturday, provide WiFi, coffee and lunch so you can spend the day learning about WebRTC with the team of the worlds technology leading WebRTC company Temasys. We'll show you around all our recent work and what it can do to bring embedded audio/video and data real-time communication into your app or website. So, if you're a web, iOS or Android developer and you'd like to hack around with WebRTC, come by! The Temasys team will judge the best work in the evening and we'll give out swanky prices to the winners! We'll max out at ~30 people, so be fast! To get you warmed up, here is Thomas' most recent talk about WebRTC and Skylink. Find the slides here: http://www.slideshare.net/serrynaimo/a-jquery-for-webrtc https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x2IHJBp2TTo Checkout http://skylink.io for more
events.location: JFDI Asia, 71 Ayer Rajah Crescent, #05-16, Singapore

events.name: Coding Dojo: Legacy Code (C# and Java)
events.description: Want to increase your fluency on working with legacy code and don't mind sweating over it? You are probably in the right place. Registration RSVP yes if you can commit that whole afternoon to code and answered yes on the 4 prerequisites below. Four Prerequisites 1. Read the book Working Effectively with Legacy Code or otherwise, read a short article about it. 2. Already understood why writing automated unit tests and Test-Driven Development is beneficial. 3. Have experience working in Java, C# or other similar Object-Oriented programming language 4. Able to attend from 1:00pm to 5:00pm *** Do not need to rsvp if you are just coming to observe during that time. *** Background Have you experienced codes that are hard to understand and is brittle? How do you deal with that more effectively? We're going to spend four solid afternoon hours to practice how to work more effectively with legacy code by having coding dojo with the Trivia Game. This code kata is used in Legacy Code Retreat and you can find the source codes here github.com/jbrains/trivia . At the end, the legacy code should become cleaner and easier to understand. A lot of the methods used will be based on Michael Feathers' Working Effectively with Legacy Code . We will spend most of the time experimenting different strategies and see how it affect the code readability and design. How does it work? • Coding dojo randori • 2 groups of 6-8 people size of different programming language. • at the end of the day, do the Code Retreat Closing Circle: gather everyone together in a circle, then go one by one sharing something about the day What legacy code do we work on? https://github.com/agilesingapore/coding_dojo_legacy_code
events.location: Odd-e Singapore - Goodland Building, 18 Roberts Lane, #05-01

events.name: .NET Developers March Meetup
events.description: Hi .NETers, We would like to invite you all to the .NET Developers Community March 2015 Meetup. For this meetup we will talk, learn and share several topics. Here is the list of topics so far; • Free topics from members . You can choose any topic related to .NET or not so related as well. For example, setting up IIS, deployment, coding, framework, etc. ( anyone wants to contribute for speaking, please contact me ). • Windows Universal App , let's make an app for Windows 8.1 , Windows Phone 8.1 and Android . - Punit Ganshani [Microsoft MVP on .NET] • S mart auto complete in WPF . Have you ever wondering what you will get when you type a keyword in a combo box or text box with auto complete? Well, you always do coding for thelist that you may aleady knew,but what if you don't know the list? I will share on some simple codes that can make the auto complete or search text box smarter than just sorting contains what you type. - Riza • How to use Azure SQL Database using .NET the right way. Using SqlConnection is good but when you need a reliable connection to Azure SQL Database or SQL Server running in a cloud environment such as in Azure Virtual Machine, you may want to be fast connected, insures connection and reliable. - Riza Let's meetup, enjoy, relax and have fun together. Btw, please send me some community jokes. :) WiFi : Available (free) Food : Available (thanks to Microsoft Singapore) Door Prize : Available (surprise, stay tune...!!!)
events.location: Microsoft Auditorium (Singapore), One Marina Boulevard, Level 21 Auditorium, Singapore 018989

events.name: Big Data for Social Good Challenge (See Details for Start/End)
events.description: THE BIG DATA FOR SOCIAL GOOD CHALLENGE BEGINS NOVEMBER 10, 2014 AND CONTINUES TO MARCH 3, 2015. CALLING ALL DEVELOPERS .... JOIN THE BIG DATA FOR SOCIAL GOOD CHALLENGE Big data exists in just about everything we use and do. It comes from phones, cars, roads, power lines, waterways, food crates, and innumerable other items you’d never think of as computers. This data speaks volumes about our collective behavior and society – so let’s use it to do something incredible! IBM invites developers and data enthusiasts to take a deep dive into real world civic issues using big data and the IBM Bluemix Analytics for Hadoop service . Analyze one of our curated datasets or bring your own (provided it meets these requirements)! Use Hadoop and your data to create a clickable and interactive data visualization to highlight insights that you’ve found. Ready to get started? $40,000 in prizes will be awarded.... Register here: http://ibmhadoop.challengepost.com/ What to Create: Participants must create a working, clickable, and interactive data visualization utilizing the Analytics for Hadoop service on IBM Bluemix. Data Requirements: Your data visualization must analyze one or more datasets included in the curated list of datasets on the Data page OR meet the data size, content, and licensing requirements described on the Data page . The total size of the Datasets analyzed must be between 500MB - 7GB in size. Check out the requirements then go get your IBM Bluemix extended promo code and check out the datasets !
events.location: Big Data for Social Good Challenge, Web only, Singapore

events.name: Lets meet at Big Data Conference in Singapore
events.description: Big Data conference is a platform for Singapore leading analytic and business intelligence leaders to address the challenges and tap on the opportunities in leveraging Big Data in this unique market. It is a marketplace for the regional business leaders and IT executives to access the very best of ideas & technologies in adopting and improving big data and analytic practices and strategies. Theme: Driving Business Success KeyNote - Erick Stephens- Chief Technology Officer -APAC , Microsoft Big Data Conference focus on:- -Best of Both Worlds: Scott Morris, Vice President Asia Pacific and Japan, Simplivity Corp Read more Benefits of attending - This event concentrates on practical applications and exploitation of big data. - It aims to cut through the marketing hype and help participants understand - The pro's and con's of the new and powerful analytic tools (both open source and proprietary) - security & governance issues and special areas of application - Emerging challenges for CIO’s and information professionals. - What are the skills set required? Why Implement Big Data? Big Data - Accelerate your business - Re-develop your products - Perform risk analysis - Keeping your data safe - Create new revenue streams - Customize your website in real time - Reducing maintenance costs - Offering enterprise-wide insights For more detail click here Registration fee for conference Early bird fee: USD $600 For online registration click here For offline registration, please send the following details to [masked] Name | Email ID | Contact No | Designation | Organization Name For this meet up group 10% discount on registration fee

events.name: Lets meet at Cloud Conference in Singapore
events.description: Cloud computing continues to be the way of the future and many studies indicate that more than 50% of all information technology will be in this new paradigm within the next five to ten years. This transformation has great implications for emerging markets which have the potential to leap frog mature markets in their adoption of cloud computing, combine cloud computing and mobile technologies to introduce unique services that can transform the lives of billions, drive a much larger scale of adoption and challenge existing price points, while presenting unique challenges in areas such as security and user interfaces to cloud computing. Theme : Cloud Computing: Opportunities, Issues, and Challenges & Big Data Innovation: Driving Business Success. KeyNote - Erick Stephens- Chief Technology Officer -APAC , Microsoft Key Topics - Worksop on Cloud Platforms -Karthikeyan Rajasekharan , Technical Architect, Cloud Platform, Asia, Google Benefits of attending • Increased speed in responding to unforeseen events. • Easy to get the latest and greatest updates. • Adoption is quick and simple. • Improved information security. • Deployment time decreases from years to months. Audience for the Conference 2014 (Not limited to) Heads of Business Development, Strategy Directors, Directors, Telecommunication Managers, Communication Directors, Heads of Sales, Heads of Call and Contact Managers, VPs of Technology, Product Managers, Business Development Managers, Storage Managers, Business Analysts For More detail click here Registration fee for conference Early bird fee: USD $600 For online registration click here For offline registration, please send the following details to [masked] Name | Email ID | Contact No | Designation | Organization Name For this meet up group 10% discount on registration fee

events.name: Lets meet at Internet of Things in Singapore
events.description: Our Conferences focuses on latest happening in IoT and how the Internet of Things will re-shape our interactions with the real and virtual worlds in the coming years. This Conference brings together leading IoT companies, Start-Ups and the developer/ Professional community to exchange their ideas with the practical application and utilization of Internet of Things. This event shall provide you the opportunity to meet IoT experts, Start Ups, attend keynote presentation and interactive sessions and network with experienced Business and Technical practitioners and Start Ups in the area of IoT. Theme: Link your World", exploring the latest happening in IoT Industry and how the Internet of Things will offer businesses and consumers. KeyNote- Alfred Hoi Wu , National Technology Officer, Microsoft IoT Agenda:- - Raspberry Pi Device for IOT Application: Pranav Pai , Founder, Inventrom For agenda click here Why Implementing the Internet of Things - Greater visibility into operations: The biggest benefit to implementing IoT is greater visibility into machine operation and plant performance. Industries have been collecting massive amounts of data for years, but it’s been a challenge to analyze this data so that it can lead to actionable items. - M2M: integral step to IoT: One of the ways to see how IoT is becoming a reality is by looking at machine-to-machine (M2M) technologies. M2M refers to machines communicating directly to other equipment without any human intervention, usually through real-time controllers and HMIs. M2M is also an integral step in the development of IoT. - Leveraging existing technologies for interoperability - Tangible results - Benefits from the cloud Benefits of Internet of things • Tracking behavior for real-time marketing; • Enhanced situational awareness; • Sensor-driven decision analytics; • Process optimization; • Optimized resource consumption; and • Instantaneous control and response in complex autonomous systems. • Ubiquitous networks • Connected computing • Ubiquitous sensors • Intelligence at the periphery of the network • Analytics-as-a-Service • Marketing automation • Supply Chain Analytics Audience for the Conference 2014 (Not limited to) - Start-Up in IoT and M2M, and have any product to showcase or any idea to share. - Venture Capitalist, and want to support IoT Start-Ups. - Professional, and works in the area of IoT and M2M - Researcher and want to see latest happening in the area of IoT. - Student and want to enhance your knowledge. For More detail click here Registration fee for conference Early bird fee: USD $600 For online registration click here For offline registration, please send the following details to [masked] Name | Email ID | Contact No | Designation | Organization Name For this meet up group 10% discount on registration fee
events.location: Village Hotel Changi,  1 Netheravon Road Singapore 508502

events.name: Meetup and Get Certified by the Linux Foundation at FOSSASIA
events.description: Join us for a Linux Foundation meetup and get certified as the Linux Engineer (LFCE) or the Linux System Administrator (LFCS) at FOSSASIA in Singapore for a special one-time discount of 100 USD off usual rates in cooperation with OlinData . We'll have a dedicated room on Saturday March 14, 2015 at Blk71 where you can sit down in all quietness and take the examination so you can walk away with one of the highest quality Linux Certification in the industry. Click here to sign up . A Linux Foundation Certified System Administrator (LFCS) has the skills to do basic to intermediate system administration from the command-line for systems running Linux. Linux Foundation Certified System Administrators are knowledgeable in the operational support of Linux systems and services. They are responsible for first line troubleshooting and analysis, and decide when to escalate issues to engineering teams. More information here: training.linuxfoundation.org/certification/lfcs Online Self-Paced Course : If you want to make sure you are prepared for the LFCS exam we have a great deal for you: By taking a special edition of the online self-paced course for the LFCS certification, you'll be well prepared for the LFCS certification and at the same time supporting FOSSASIA. Please go here to proceed. A Linux Foundation Certified Engineer (LFCE) possesses a wider range and greater depth of skills than the Linux Foundation Certified System Administrator (LFCS). Linux Foundation Certified Engineers are responsible for the design and implementation of system architecture. They provide an escalation path and serve as Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) for the next generation of system administration professionals. More information here: http://training.linuxfoundation.org/certification/lfcs Links FOSSASIA: http://fossasia.org Twitter: https://twitter.com/fossasia Certification: http://fossasia.org/linux
events.location: NUS Plug-In@Blk71, Ayer Rajah Crescent, #05-16, Singapore

events.name: Build your own distro with Lubuntu's Julien Lavergne
events.description: How useful would it be to give your customers a ready configured OS, that suits their needs right away? Or just how cool would it be to create your own OS for fun? Julien Lavergne Lubuntu maintainer will show us how to create your own distro based on Lubuntu. In the workshop you will learn several ways to to create a distro with different tools. We will show you how to start work from different base systems or distributions. You will learn about what choices are available for different use cases and how you can adapt your distribution for a specific country or for a specific showcase with your own applications. About Julien Lavergne Julien is a contributor in Ubuntu and Debian for 10 years. He is a Debian maintainer and an Ubuntu developer mainly working on the Lubuntu project as the main developer. https://gilir.wordpress.com | http://twitter.com/gilir Links Lubuntu: http://lubuntu.net FOSSASIA http://fossasia.org Twitter http://twitter.com/fossasia
events.location: NUS Plug-In@Blk71, Ayer Rajah Crescent, #05-16, Singapore

events.name: Front End TL;DR March 2015
events.description: Let's visit migme, a startup that has been around forever and is currently reinventing itself as a social entertainment destination, complete with IPO and fresh funding from Foxconn last year. Come to learn about the host company but more importantly to learn front end tech technology. FEDS aims to showcase startups doing cool front end work, but also to sharpen our skills. We will split up into small teams, pick a topic of interest (e.g. library, framework, tool) and collaborate on it for an hour or so. Then present our findings for the common good, and the most interesting team wins a fabulous prize! Schedule: Every third Monday of the month. Different venue each time. 7:00pm — Arrival, registration, seating 7:10pm — Intro talk 7:30pm — Teams work on mini challenges 8:30pm — Presentations, awards 9:00pm — The end. More info: http://feds.strikingly.com/ PS: Bring a laptop and show up a bit earlier to get set up on the wifi.
events.location: Migme Hq

events.name: Making with Cardboard
events.description: Strong furniture can be made out of cardboard. The programme will go through the basics of making cardboard furniture using “free form” design and everyday materials. Participants will also be introduced to 3D modelling of furniture and how to convert their models into printable pdfs which can then be used in the building of cardboard furniture
events.location: Toa Payoh Hdb Hub

events.name: Making toys and games
events.description: Get your hands dirty as you make your own toys and games. Make glowing crystals, crane mechanisms, origami toys and much more
events.location: Science Centre Singapore

events.name: Front End TL;DR April 2015
events.description: We are being hosted by Smartkarma, a young startup disrupting the financial industry. They are located in Changi Business Park (Expo MRT) because that's where most financial institutions have their IT operations. FEDS is about hands-on, collaborative learning. Join the session if you'd like to learn new front end technology. Schedule: Every third Monday of the month. Different venue each time. 7:00pm — Arrival, registration, seating 7:10pm — Intro talk 7:30pm — Teams work on mini challenges 8:30pm — Presentations, awards 9:00pm — The end. More info: http://feds.strikingly.com/ PS: Bring a laptop and show up a bit earlier to get set up on the wifi.
events.location: Smartkarma

events.name: Maker Faire Singapore
events.description: Maker Faire Singapore is back for the 4th year! And this time we are featured, thanks to the enthusiastic support from the Maker Community in Singapore
events.location: 15, Tampines street 11

events.name: Hebocon Singapore (Robotics competition for the technically ungifted)
events.description: The search for Singapore's worst robot will take place some time this year (most likely in July 2015). Known as Japan’s "worst robot competition”, the purpose of the HEBOCON event is to find out which crappy robot is the ultimate failure of them all through a sumo-styled wrestling battle. Preparations are being made to bring this quirky robotic competition to Singapore. We are looking for venue hosts, sponsors, contributors and supporters for this inaugural event. More details about guidelines and rules of competition will be announced in March 2015. Meanwhile stay cute and unskillful! If you're interested to participate, please indicate your attendance here. Thank you. *the date indicated below is a tentative one. the confirmed schedule will be release in Mar 2015 For more information about HEBOCON, check out the official page at https://www.facebook.com/Hebocon.Official
events.location: TBD
